author: S P
text:
‘Same court had earlier held setting bus on fire with students inside was highest degree of brutality’

The family of V. Kokilavani, one of the three girls who were charred to death when AIADMK cadre set fire to a bus in February 2000 in Dharmapuri, is distraught over the Supreme Court’s order commuting the death sentences of the three convicts in the case on Friday.

“The same court had earlier held that setting the bus on fire with students inside was the highest degree of brutality. Now, it has reversed its order. My daughter was burnt alive and my family has not got justice,” was how Mr Veerasamy, Kokilavani’s father reacted. He felt that the Supreme Court, by commuting the death sentence of the convicts has nullified the judgments awarded by the trial court and appellate courts.

‘Can’t accept argument’

“Would any father, whose son or daughter was burnt alive, accept the argument that such crimes were a result of mob psychology,” Mr. Veerasamy asked.

‘Painful 16 years’

According to him, Ms. Kokilavani’s death had a life-changing effect on his family. His wife has remained bed-ridden.

“The past 16 years has been painful and today’s verdict has pierced our hearts,” he said.

Survived by two sons, Mr. Veerasamy rents out a tempo and earns his livelihood in A.S. Pettai in Namakkal town.
title: Justice has been denied: victim’s family
